message.content:
cs.IT, cs.CR, cs.DS, cs.DC, cs.CC. 

The paper deals with constructing capacity-achieving linear codes for private information retrieval (PIR) from non-colluding databases, which involves information theory (cs.IT) and cryptography (cs.CR). The use of maximum distance separable (MDS) codes suggests a connection to coding theory (cs.DS), while the focus on minimum message size and sub-packetization factor suggests a connection to distributed systems (cs.DS) and distributed computing (cs.DC). Finally, the use of novel code constructions and a matching converse suggests a connection to complexity theory (cs.CC).
